message_1: What is the product formed when methyl bromide reacts with aqueous sodium hydroxide and what type of nucleophilic substitution reaction is occurring?
message_2:
When methyl bromide (CH3Br) reacts with aqueous sodium hydroxide (NaOH), a nucleophilic substitution reaction occurs. Specifically, it is an SN2 reaction (substitution nucleophilic bimolecular). In this reaction, the hydroxide ion (OH-) from sodium hydroxide acts as a nucleophile and attacks the electrophilic carbon in methyl bromide, replacing the bromide ion (Br-).

The products formed in this reaction are methanol (CH3OH) and sodium bromide (NaBr). The balanced chemical equation for this reaction is:

CH3Br + NaOH â†’ CH3OH + NaBr
